dataset.title: Predictors of individual variation in the performance of animals in cognitive tests

creator.organizationName: Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge
Centre for Ecology and Conservation, University of Exeter

abstract.para: This file contains data collected as part of a study that is summarized in the following publication: "Individual variation in cognitive performance: developmental and evolutionary perspectives", by Alex Thornton & Dieter Lukas, published in Philosopohical Transactions of the Royal Society B 367: 2773-2783 (2012 http://rstb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/367/1603/2773.short The study was a meta-analysis investigating the factors that influence the performance of animals in cognitive testing. There are five separate datasets, all of which report data extracted from earlier publications. The file contains (i) data that formed the basis for the results presented in the paper, (ii) all data collected as part of the study, including entries with missing or unclear information that were removed before analyses, (iii) data that was collected during a preliminary study, where the variables differ from those in the final dataset, but some studies might appear in both, (iv) and (v) additional data from studies that, while listing individual performance, did not link this to further detail about the individuals.

intellectualRights.para: The data is being made available to the public scientific domain with rights similar to CC BY 4.0 attribution.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Data was collated from a number of previous studies that were performed with individuals in captive settings around the world. Further details are available in the datasheets.

section.title: Data extraction
section.para: We obtained data from published studies of object permanence (OP); understanding of the functional properties of objects (FPO); causal reasoning ‘folk physics’ tasks (CR); and mark tests of mirror self-recognition (MSR). Studies were identified by searching for these keywords in ISI Web of Science and Google Scholar, and by looking up references cited in or citing these studies. For each study, we recorded information on characteristics of the individual animal performing the task, the success rate in completing the task, and information on the study setup.
